data.text:
Hi,

could you, please, tell me, which one is correct (if any)?

The town (X) has good bus connections with its neighbourhood/ vicinity.

Thank you.

I wouldn't use 'neighbourhood', as this refers to a local residential area.

I suspect the best option may be to determine whether the places the town has connections with are other towns, suburbs and so on and attach 'surrounding'.

=> The town X has good bus connections with [the surrounding area/surrounding boroughs/surrounding suburbs/nearby towns, etc.]

I liked all of cropje jnr's suggestions, though in American English it is unlikely that someone would say borough. The main way borough is used in the US is to refer to a certain type of animal dwellings but we understand the meaning given by cropje jnr.

Borough is a very appropriate suggestion in my opinion, depending on the city/country. What you're thinking of are burrows.

You're right mrbilal about the spelling. I got mixed up. It still isn't a likely word choice in the US though. I suppose it is more common in Canada.

Some US cities, notably New York, have boroughs. (Manhattan, for example, is one of the boroughs.)

And, checking a little further, I have found that New Jersey has incorporated towns called boroughs, and what many US states call counties, Alaska calls boroughs.

You're right mrbilal about the spelling. I got mixed up. It still isn't a likely word choice in the US though. I suppose it is more common in Canada.

I believe some US cities and states have boroughs, especially New York City. In Canada, boroughs are fairly uncommon, the most being in Quebec.

I had not thought of New York City. I can't think of any other areas in the US like that, so I would say the other choices provided are safer options.

I think the thread drifted in other lanes and no one answered the specific question. In what case should I use "neighborhood" or "vicinity"?

I'm going to give another example for better undertanding:

This could be a good neighborhood/vicinity for a family to live

Thank you.

Do all of these work and mean more or less the same thing?

There's quite a lot of crime in this area.

There's quite a lot of crime in this neighbourhood.

There's quite a lot of crime in the vicinity.
